Award.AwardTitle: Development of High Performance Control Systems for Wind Response Mitigation

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
In recent years, there has been an increased shift towards the performance-based analysis and design of buildings to resist natural hazards such as earthquakes and wind. The new paradigm of incorporating high performance control systems to increase building performance under these hazards is promising. Control systems are adaptable devices capable of high energy absorption that would significantly reduce the structural response. However, their design is not holistically integrated into the structural design process in a way that would ensure attaining the targeted performance level of response. This is mostly due to the high range of variability in available control systems, the uncertainties associated with the performance of the control systems and the building, variability in the type of loading in a multi-hazard scheme, and unclear definition of performance measures when it comes to wind loads. The goal of this research is to develop a holistic integration control systems directly at the design stage, with particular attention to structures subjected to a variety of wind hazards, including thunderstorms, hurricanes, gust-fronts, and tornadoes. This methodology will empower the design engineers with technical and financial arguments supporting the integration of control systems within the structural system. By validating the potential benefits of control systems, there will be an increasing number of applications of these systems, enabling an integrated design approach for meeting the performance criteria set for structural response in windstorms.

The focus of this project is to develop a probabilistic performance-based methodology for structures equipped with high performance control systems. The objective of the project is twofold: (1) to establish a performance-based methodology that includes the variability of control systems and (2) to support the integration of control systems for wind response mitigation. Loads and response data will be produced using physical models of structures subjected to a variety of wind loads using a boundary-layer wind tunnel, and tornado and microburst simulation facilities. The notion of control system performance, including sensor failure, power failure, and controller sub-performance will be integrated in the procedure using an integrated probabilistic approach. Control systems will be developed following the procedure, which will include a novel variable friction device. Physics based numerical simulations will be developed to validate and demonstrate the performance-based methodology for control systems. These simulations will enable the analysis of life-cycle performance of a structure equipped with control systems under a set of scenarios. Novel quantitative metrics will be formulated to characterize structural performance versus performance of the control systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project has developed and studied tools enabling the holistic integration of control systems directly at the design stage, with particular attention to structures subjected to a variety of wind hazards, including thunderstorms, hurricanes, gust-fronts, and tornadoes. This was done by establishing a performance-based design methodology that accounted for uncertainties in the controlled system, and by producing data supporting the integration of control systems for wind response mitigation.

In particular, the project yielded (1) a set of various prototype buildings, enabling validation through numerical simulations; (2) a new methodology to predict realistic wind loads and response of a tall and flexible structure in any type of wind storms, reducing reliance on expensive full tests; (3) a quantification of tornado threats on tall buildings, concluding that they can be significant; (4) a methodology to conduct life-cycle analysis of controlled structures exposed to winds in an uncertain environment, enabling the estimation of savings produced by a control system over the structure’s life; (5) a formal quantification of uncertainties in the control loop, providing the field with critical information for conducting simulations in more realistic environments; (6) a new physics-informed data-based algorithm for conducting life-cycle analysis, reducing computing demand significantly; and (7) data showing that high-performance control systems can result in important savings over the structure’ life, therefore adding arguments in favor of deploying these systems in the field to improve structural resiliency.

The research project advanced the fields of structural engineering, wind engineering, and structural control, smart systems and structures, and computer sciences by (1) providing means to rapidly simulate structural responses to wind loads, instead of relying on computational fluid dynamics; (2) providing performance thresholds associated with wind responses, as well as cost functions, to investigate losses associated with excessive motion; (3) empowering designers with a methodology to holistically integrate high-performance control systems within the structural design phase; and (4) enabling advanced modeling techniques for studying complex engineering systems. Results have been disseminated at various conferences in the form of presentations and conference proceedings, and in highly ranked journals in the form of technical articles.

The project also contributed to the education of the future workforce by (1) demonstrating aeroelastic tall building model vibrations in ISU’s AABL Wind and Gust Tunnel and Tornado Simulator Facilities to K-12 students and teachers, with the objective to raise public awareness of wind hazards in general and of the benefits of research into these problems; (2) training a group of three Ph.D students and five undergraduate students that included members of under-represented groups; (3) presenting cutting-edge results in an undergraduate class and two graduate classes, contributing to producing the next leaders in engineering by exposing them to modern engineering problems and solutions; and (4) involving graduate students in presenting research findings during research meetings and at conferences, and in writing technical papers.The knowledge and the skills gained through students’ participation in this project will empower their future career development in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics.
